author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: It's difficult for a user to predict the MEV on their own tx, esp cause they're often trying to reduce it. Also there's lots of tx that don't have any MEV, such as ETH and erc20 transfers, new contracts deployed and called etc

author: Deleted User
content:
Apologies if someone thinks this message is slightly off-topic.
I’ve never had a Twitter account, so I can’t contact the guys behind ultrasound.money. I hope they see this message here. Otherwise, I would appreciate it very much if someone, maybe <@269786774660710400>, let them know about it.
While everybody’s focusing now on how much ETH is being burnt net, as far as I can tell nobody’s looking at it in relative terms and charting the supply rate of change (i.e. the supply’s first derivative), or inflation rate, as a % per annum, in order to see how it’s changed after London. IMO this metric is the most telling of all and should therefore be included in any supply chart either as a a secondary chart attached right underneath the supply chart (preferably) or as a second line inside the supply chart itself, as in this old EthHub chart. Thanks.

author: justindrake
content: will pass on; many more metrics coming to ultrasound.money

author: Deleted User
content: I appreciate that. Looking forward to seeing those new metrics
